case: A 73-year-old Black presents with acute, severe, pleuritic, central, non-radiating chest pain, and tachycardia after undergoing an esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy.
differential: Esophageal perforation (Boerhaave syndrome or iatrogenic perforation)
Acute pericarditis (secondary to procedural complication or infection)
Pulmonary embolism (possibly provoked by immobility or underlying risk factors)
Cardiac tamponade (secondary to perforation or complication)
Acute aortic syndrome (dissection or intramural hematoma, though less likely post-endoscopy)

case: A 73-year-old Black presents with acute, severe, pleuritic, central, non-radiating chest pain, and tachycardia after undergoing an esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy.
differential: Esophageal perforation (Boerhaave syndrome or iatrogenic injury from endoscopy)
Acute pericarditis (possibly secondary to procedure-induced injury or infection)
Acute gastritis or peptic ulcer perforation

case: A 73-year-old Black presents with acute, severe, pleuritic, central, non-radiating chest pain, and tachycardia after undergoing an esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy.
differential: Esophageal perforation (Boerhaave syndrome or iatrogenic perforation)
Acute pericarditis (post-procedural or secondary to perforation)
Pulmonary embolism (increased risk peri-procedurally and presents with pleuritic pain and tachycardia)
Myocardial infarction (especially atypical presentation in elderly and Black patients)
Aspiration pneumonitis (peri-procedural event leading to pleuritic pain)
Aortic dissection (less likely, but possible with acute severe chest pain)
Gastroesophageal reflux or severe esophagitis (post-endoscopy complication)
Cardiac tamponade (secondary to perforation or pericardial involvement)
